A huge water tank is being built on First street, close to the main fence and near Church street. The tank is for fire purposes only, and will be of great use to people living away from the river.

Mr. H. A. Head has closed his photo studio for a few months. He will not be back until after striking the railway, but will be back early in the spring.

Sept. 8th, N. and M. Sproul, Hartley and the Diamond Telegraph service, left Troy last week for a tour of inspection along the line, and will be back early in the spring.

D.C. McIlwain & Co. have moved into their new offices. Their doors were open last Friday when they will be pleased to see all their old customers or anyone else desiring anything in the line of hardware.

The nominations in East Assiniboia for the representative to the Legislative Par-
liament took place on Wednesday last.

The Hon. E. Darragh, chairman of the meeting, nominated Mr. H. W. McLeod, the only candidate nominated and he was therefore declared elected by acclamation.

The marriage of Mr. H. W. McLeod and Miss Christy Olsen took place at the residence of the bride's mother, in the town of Prince Albert, on Friday last, amidst the assembled of a few friends.

We wish the young couple long life, happiness and prosperity.

Judge McIntire, wife and family ar-
rived back in town on Tuesday.

The Judge and family have been away at a friend's in the east.

Miss Cunningham, of King Street, also, arrived Monday.

Mrs. McIntire, also, came back from the Jubilee.

The ladies of Island Lake settlement will give a harvest dinner dinner Mr. and Mrs. McIntire, on Friday next, the 21st inst., at noon, at the Methodist church.

The Lake is about to be opened up for a short time.

After the dinner dinner of all kinds will be indulged in and there are several large parties of the visitors.

The C. C. Band will be in attendance.

A good time is guaranteed.

The great American eagle is stirring for game over the fisheries question. The Senate and people of the great American Republic are threatening all sorts of vengeance on unhappy Canada. They have even now dispatched their extra navy men to Canada, following up the fact that Yankee fishermen and poachers are not punished as they deserve in their lackless acts. Our Dominion might tremble for the result were the Yankees to land in force, but as it consists only of one rotten limb which they are pleased to call a flag-staff, the danger is not so great as to cause much alarm. We would call the attention of Senator Frye to the fact that the Fisheries Question is a little like the Panama Canal; there is a little market which might be available in case of an emergency. The person referred to was last heard from at St. Thomas, Ont., and judging from the tone of his remarks we believe he would be most happy to assist Uncle Sam with the above-mentioned market, especially as he has not had the opportunity of using it against Canada for some time. The United States is now passing retaliatory laws. They expect by denying Canada certain commercial facilities to force her into surrendering her valuable fisheries. But the consequences of such a course will suffer as much from pursuing such a course as we will. We are no longer dependent on American roads to do our carrying trade. We have our own shipping lines, steamships, and lines of railway, and can very secretly smile at the pettish actions of Brother Jonathan. The London Times says, editorially, that "Retaliation will prove enough to make a grip on some necks within Canada, and put a hand against it, and that the British Government will stand by the rights of Canada."

The Hon. Walter Laing, of Saskatchewan market fame, and leader of the Reform party in the Dominion Parliament, has been heard from again. This time in connection with the Fisheries Treaty. Speaking at St. Thomas lately he boldly took the part of the United States as against Canada, and declared that the time had come when there should be closer relations between the two countries, in short that Canada should surrender her rights and her existing prosperity to Uncle Sam. This is the position taken by the Liberal leader, but fortunately he does not voice the sentiments of the Canadian nation. The Reform party, under Mr. Laing, are reputedly by the phrase "Canadian," such topics as the Globe being especially strong in its denunciation of his unpatriotic utterances. It declares that the Conservative Government has been so successful in its administration that the Liberals would have had to do what they have done in power and that the people should support the Government in this crisis, and that the fisheries question will yet have to be settled by an International Commission. The Globe, although it regards the annexationists, also condemns Laing's language, and upholds the Government in a hearty manner.

Gabriel Dumont has announced his intention of returning to Saskatchewan this month.

The Manitoba wheat crop for this year is estimated at 20,000,000 bushels. This will be 8,000,000 bushels in excess of 1887. In Dakota, on the other hand, the crops are a failure, the damage resulting not only from them from frost, but from wind, heat and disease.

Sir Chas. Tupper, Canadian High Commissioner in England, has been created a G.C.M.G. His Excellency, the Hon. J. H. Thompson, Canadian Minister of Justice, has received the honor of knighthood, he being created a C.C.M.G. These honors have been conferred by Her Majesty the Queen in recognition of services rendered to Sir Charles and Mr. Thompson as members of the late Fisheries Commission. We congratulate the worth knights on being made the recipients of such high distinctions.

The Bathfield Herald has its personal Indian scare in a recent number. The only reason given for the panic is the statement that some Indians have been seen about where perhaps they ought not to be, namely, idle white man; and then Bathfield wants more Police. We do not believe there is any necessity for more Police or elsewhere from the Indian, but to allay the fears of the fearful and give a greater feeling of security, we would like to see either more Police in the district or militia organizations.

TOWN COUNCIL

The Town Council held a special meeting on Monday evening last. His Worship Mayor Jane presiding. The councillors present were McPhail, Savory, Agnew, Kowles, Davis, and Johnstone.

A communication was received from Miss Baker, secretary of the Ladies Aid Society in connection with the Presbyte Church. Miss Baker had visited the Town Hall on Oct. 4th. Granted.

Louis Schmidt asked for revision of terms in connection with the Solicitor Isaac (Officer probably). Nothing printed committed and license issued. The application was laid over for further consideration. Carried.

Licenses were granted to the following: cattle dealer, A. Murray & Sons; beef stables: C. Byrne, dray; D. Pollock, horse; F. Murray, sheep; S. Rollins, swine; David Macklin, hairdresser; James McDonald, dry.

The following a warrant was issued W. H. Fish, St. Jan, Mattaws, St.

REPORTS

The Finance and Assessment Committee recommended the following at its meeting: Mr. J. McPhail, pres.; Mr. A. Savory, sec.; Messrs. E. Pollock & Edm. Murray, members. Of the Town Books to be sold, Mr. J. Sirag, owner of the books, was not present. Mr. D. Williamson if sold was referred back to the Board of Works for their decision. The Fire, Water and Light Committee submitted the following report: That no new fire hydrant is required near the fire station to satisfy the requirements of the fire department, and that they have located, on the northeast side of First Avenue, near Mr. John McCaggan's residence, Adopted.

A petition was received from Mr. William Dillon & Co., 2nd Ave. Ext. Etobicoke. A warrant was issued granting the privilege of using electricity at the rate of $1 per year for the building occupied by Mr. John McCaggan's residence. Adopted.

McPhail moved that Constable Agnew be requested to have an examination done at this time of the rugged condition and dirt and other obstructions from the commissioners' feet from the sidewalks and streets, and all property where he could find any other obstruction or trouble, and to advise how to amend the license by law. Carried.

Agnew reminded Mr. Savory nothing had been done about the sidewalks and held that Mr. Savory was not fulfilling his duties. Agnew then moved that Mr. Savory be instructed by the Board of Works, that the Board of Works shall take steps to see that the sidewalks were not obstructed by anyone else. Carried.

Remaining business discussed and Carried.

SYMPOSIUM ON THE HISTORY OF THE NEW YORK STATE UNIVERSITY

Speakers included Professors Washburn, Dunbar, and others, who discussed various aspects of the history of the University. The event was well attended and drew praise and attention from those present.

AMERICAN SCHOLARSHIP PRIZE

The American Scholarship Prize, valued at $500, was awarded to Eliza Jones for her outstanding academic performance. The award ceremony took place at the University's main hall with speeches given by distinguished scholars.

ENSIONALIST PHILOSOPHY AND THE ENVIRONMENT ACADEMY

A symposium focused on the advancements of environmental studies through the lens of Enolationist philosophy. Panelists explored themes such as sustainability, ethics, and impact assessments, fostering a deeper understanding of the interplay between nature and human actions.

PUBLIC SPEECHES AND DEBATES

Public speeches and debates attracted a large audience, engaging the community in thoughtful discussions on pressing issues concerning technology, climate change, and social justice.

LIBERAL AND PLAYFUL EXPERIENCE 

Liberal and Playful Experience offers a comprehensive guide covering various aspects of life, offering insights into personal growth and societal trends.

THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE IN CANADA

The series "The English Language in Canada" explores linguistic diversity across provinces and regions, emphasizing the role of English in education, culture, and economy.

NEWSPAPERS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF TORONTO

This issue delves into the rich legacy of newspapers published by students and faculty at the University of Toronto, tracing their development and importance in academic discourse.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

CALGARY.

From the Herald, August 29.

The fire has given the house after their escape towards Dundas. They have been assisted to escape by some men.

Regina, Aug. 28. Yesterday afternoon, before W. H. Horrigan, Esq., a commissioner of the Dominion Police, August 25, Mr. Donald MacLeod, who was committed to stand his trial at the Superior Court in Calgary in November next, Mr. Donald MacLeod, Crown Attorney, appeared before the court, the prisoner for digging up bones from Mr. MacLeod's domain. Mr. H. Lay, M. P. M. A., appeared for the prisoner. The prisoner gave bail himself in $600 and Messrs. Banman and Martin in $300 each. The prisoner will be sent back into custody and will appear in proper person to answer for his further crimes.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald, Aug. 25.

Joe, an Indian, a few days ago killed six buffalo out of a herd of seven that he had in stock near Red Deer Forks.

The proposed Mounted Police campment at Saskatoon, which was to have been formed next week, has been postponed.

Mr. Dunmall will carry on the most market on his own account. Mr. Barker having withdrawn from that business.

Harvesting is now general, and the result is everywhere satisfactory, the crops being generally good and healthy. The extremely hot weather of the past month brought on the grain with marvelous rapidity, and there are apparently so many new and promising crops that answers as to the grand result which will close the effort.

Mr. Otten has sown about two-thirds of the way up the big hill and wants water at the depth of seven feet. The soil is about three feet below the level of the river. At the foot of the hill he got three feet of water in a four-foot hole.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, Aug. 25.

The present hot weather keeps the river at a high stage. There are all well.

Mr. Grant has a splendid crop of barley ready to cut. Also an excellent crop of potatoes.

Mrs. Ingles, of Fort Saskatchewan, reported a swarm of bees a couple of weeks ago by express.

Mr. Paterson, A. Mitchell, who started for British Yorke last spring, are now in Seattle, Washington Territory.

Double the usual amount of landing between is required to make up for this season's losses. The rate is so heavy; the twins sell at 22 cents per pound.

Although the tomato plants show a vigorous growth, the yield is not bounteous liberally the general experience is that no fruit has formed. The reason has yet to be discovered.

LETHBRIDGE.

From the News, August 29.

Tenders for the laying of sidewalks and crossings have been advertised by the Council Grant Committee. We hope they will be completed in time for the principal places in town.

On Saturday afternoon last Horse Man was up before J. Champoux, J. F., charged with absconding with the property of Mrs. White-France, the owner of the horse. On the charge being taken, he was committed for trial.

On Tuesday last the Hon. Mr. Bowden and party were being driven across the prairie when they were treated to a runaway by way of surprise. The bit of one of the leaders broke and the horse became uncontrollable. They were brought to a standstill before any damage was done.

A large rock slide occurred from Peak Mountain, but the road was kept on Tuesday night about half past nine. Peak Mountain is about a quarter-mile up the Spray River. Mr. E. H. Miller, Hotel, a mile away from the village. Two loaded rocks as large as an ordinary house rolled down a distance of 3,000 feet, ploughing up trees and killing cattle in their course. The noise of the falling rocks aroused the whole town and members of their last hour had come, others thought that a train had run away and there was considerable consternation throughout.
